<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

	<title>JSFireTruck: Exploring Malicious JavaScript Using JSF*ck as an Obfuscation Technique</title>
	<meta name="description" content="In an extensive campaign affecting 270k webpages, compromised websites were injected with the esoteric JavaScript programming style JSF*ck to redirect users to malicious content. <script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"JSFireTruck: Exploring Malicious JavaScript Using JSF*ck as an Obfuscation Technique","name":"JSFireTruck: Exploring Malicious JavaScript Using JSF*ck as an Obfuscation Technique","description":"In an extensive campaign affecting 270k webpages, compromised websites were injected with the esoteric JavaScript programming style JSF*ck to redirect users to malicious content.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation\/","datePublished":"June 12, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nWe recently discovered a large-scale campaign that has been compromising legitimate websites with injected, obfuscated JavaScript code. Threat actors commonly use this type of campaign to invisibly redirect victims from legitimate websites to malicious pages that serve malware, exploits and spam.\r\n\r\nThe campaign uses a JavaScript obfuscation technique known as JSF*ck (profanity masked). Due to the profanity in the term, we refer to the method in the remainder of this article by using the nickname JSFireTruck.\r\n\r\nOur key findings are:\r\n\r\n \tMultiple websites have been identified with injected malicious JavaScript that uses JSFireTruck obfuscation, which is composed primarily of the symbols []+${}\r\n \tThe code's obfuscation hides its true purpose, hindering analysis\r\n \tThe injected code checks the website referrer, and if the referrer is a search engine, the code redirects victims to malicious URLs\r\n \tRetroactive hunting on VirusTotal and our internal telemetry revealed thousands of related samples, indicating this is a widespread infection campaign affecting many websites\r\n \tInjected JavaScript will redirect users to websites that can lead to malware downloads or other harmful activities, like malvertising and traffic monetization\r\n\r\nThe campaign's scale and stealth pose a significant threat. The widespread nature of these infections suggests a coordinated effort to compromise legitimate websites as attack vectors for further malicious activities.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nMalvertising, JavaScript\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBackground\r\nAttackers compromise legitimate websites, so these sites will silently redirect viewer traffic for various malicious purposes, like malware downloads, traffic monetization or malvertising. Our telemetry recently revealed a large group of websites that were injected with malicious obfuscated JavaScript, as shown below in Figure 1.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142879\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"834\"] Figure 1. Example of malicious injected JavaScript found in the HTML pages.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOn an initial look, the JavaScript code consists of a few characters like []+${} and some numbers. The code's purpose isn't readily apparent, prompting further investigation. We soon discovered that this code partially implements the JSFireTruck programming technique.\r\n\r\nOur telemetry detected 269,552 webpages infected with JavaScript code using JSFireTruck in the three months from March 26, 2025, through April 25, 2025. This data is shown below in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142890\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. Telemetry data shows over 200,000 infected pages.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs indicated in Figure 2, we saw a notable increase in detections for this campaign starting on April 12, 2025. Ultimately, this campaign is widespread and has infected many websites.\r\nAnalyzing the JavaScript Obfuscation\r\nThe injected JavaScript code with JSFireTruck obfuscation uses a limited set of characters and numbers, as shown in Figure 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142901\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 3. Injected code as found in the HTML page consists of only [, ], (, ), !, + and numbers.[\/caption]&nbsp;\r\n\r\nThis is unexpected compared to examples of malicious injected JavaScript code we normally find, as there is no single variable or function name that seems to be executed at first glance. But publicly available information indicates that the symbols from this code are ASCII characters used for JSFireTruck.\r\n\r\nJSFireTruck is a branch of an earlier JavaScript obfuscation technique originally released in 2009 called JJEncode. This earlier technique was used in previous campaigns to obfuscate JavaScript, like Kahu Security's 2013 analysis of a compromised automobile forum. JJEncode uses the following 18 ASCII characters: []()!+,\\\"$.:;_{}~=\r\n\r\nBy August 2012, a user named aemkei created a GitHub repository for JSFireTruck, where they reduced the number of ASCII characters to the following six symbols:\r\n[\r\n]\r\n(\r\n)\r\n!\r\n+\r\nThe example from Figure 3 above appears to combine JSFireTruck with other obfuscation techniques.\r\nJavaScript Obfuscation Through Type Coercion\r\nJavaScript has different value types like strings, numbers, booleans, arrays and objects. If we use two mismatched value types together, such as strings and numbers, JavaScript uses type coercion to make the code work. Type coercion results in converting a value from one type to another.\r\n\r\nType coercion has various uses, such as displaying a number in JavaScript code as a string. For example, the toString() method will display a numeric value as an ASCII string.\r\n\r\nJSFireTruck relies on type coercion, which automatically converts its limited set of symbols into the various ASCII characters or numeric values used in unobfuscated JavaScript code.\r\n\r\nFor example, to generate a number value of zero, we can use the following characters:\r\n+[]\r\nIf we debug the characters +[] in Chrome or Edge DevTools, we find these characters translate to a value of zero, as shown below in Figure 4.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142912\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 4. Using DevTools to convert JavaScript code +[] to its numeric value of zero.[\/caption]&nbsp;\r\n\r\nHow is this possible? In JavaScript code, [] represents an empty array, and if we prefix it with +, JavaScript will use type coercion to convert the empty array value into a number. Since [] contains no value, using + converts it to a value of zero.\r\n\r\nUsing this approach, we can generate the number 1 with the following characters:\r\n+!![]\r\nBecause the [] array is blank, prefixing it with ! converts it to the boolean value of False. Adding a second ! converts it to a boolean value of True. Prefixing the entire string with + converts it to a numeric value. When converting True to a number, its value is 1.\r\n\r\nWe can generate other numbers by adding the same +!![] text, which represents an additional value of 1. For example, we can generate the number 2 from:\r\n+!![] + +!![]\r\nWe can generate the number 3 from:\r\n+!![] + +!![] + +!![]\r\nSimilarly, we can increase the numeric value by adding more +!![] text to the string.\r\n\r\nWe can also generate characters using this approach. For example, to create the character a, we can use the following code:\r\n(![]+[])[1]\r\nIn this example, ![] becomes the boolean value False as mentioned earlier. Adding the symbols for a blank array [] makes the string ![]+[], which represents False + no value. JavaScript uses type coercion to convert ![]+[] to the ASCII string False.\r\n\r\nTo select the second letter of the word False, we need the first offset (second character) of the string. We do this by enclosing the original symbols in parentheses and using 1 for the offset, so (![]+[])[1] is the code that generates the letter a.\r\n\r\nFigure 5 shows Edge DevTools confirming that (![]+[])[1] generates the letter a.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142923\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 5. Analysis of JavaScript code in DevTools showing how to generate the character a with this approach.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nIn a similar manner, we can generate the character b using the following string:\r\n({}+[])[2]\r\nIn this example, {} represents an empty object. Adding the symbols for a blank array [] makes the string {}+[]. JavaScript's type coercion changes {}+[] to the ASCII string [object Object]. To select the second letter of the word object in the string [object Object], we need the second offset (third character) of that string. We do this by enclosing the original symbols in parentheses and using 2 for the offset, so ({}+[])[2] is the code that generates the letter b.\r\n\r\nFigure 6 shows Edge DevTools confirming that ({}+[])[2] generates the letter b.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142934\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 6. Analysis of JavaScript code in DevTools showing how to generate the character b with this approach.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nBy using different combinations of symbols and terms, JavaScript's type coercion can generate various ASCII strings. We can use the offset method to select each letter of the alphabet and different symbols from the resulting strings. Figure 7 shows examples analyzed in DevTools that result in the letters c, d, e and f.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142945\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"800\"] Figure 7. Examples of this obfuscation approach in DevTools that generate the letters c, d, e and f.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nFrom this approach, we can further condense the symbols to the six used by JSFireTruck: [, ], (, ), !, and +. For example, we can generate the letters a and b from the following characters:\r\na = (![]+[])[+!![]]\r\nb = ({}+[])[+!![] + +!![]]\r\nBy using the JSFireTruck obfuscation technique, any JavaScript code can be obfuscated by using just six characters. Furthermore, attackers can combine JSFireTruck with other obfuscation techniques to make malicious JavaScript more difficult for defenders to analyze.\r\n\r\nBut using these obfuscation techniques has two drawbacks:\r\n\r\n \tThe obfuscated code usually involves a large amount of text\r\n \tDue to the repeated use of the same characters, the obfuscated code is easy to detect, even if it is not easy to analyze\r\n\r\nExample of Malicious Code\r\nWe now understand how just six characters can represent any JavaScript code. Malware authors use this technique to make code analysis more difficult.\r\n\r\nDuring our analysis, we found thousands of websites with this type of obfuscated JavaScript injected into their webpages.\r\n\r\nFigure 8 below shows an example of the injected script following the String.fromCharCode function.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142956\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 8. Example of injected code starting from the String.fromCharCode function.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOf note, the obfuscated script contains an additional String.fromCharCode function, which presents another obfuscation layer.\r\nDecoding the Obfuscated Script\r\nWe can decode the obfuscated JavaScript shown in Figure 8 through various publicly available deobfuscators for JSFireTruck. We automated our decoding process using one such tool.\r\n\r\nWhen the script from Figure 8 is decoded, the output appears to be further obfuscated as shown in Figure 9.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142967\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 9. Decoded JSFireTruck script shows that it's further obfuscated.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe decoded script remains obfuscated, using an array variable $. It then accesses the values at different indexes within this array.\r\n\r\nThese array variables are present inside the script shown in Figure 10.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142978\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 10. Injected code showing use of String.fromCharCode function used as an array.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIf we decode these character arrays and use them to replace the characters in the previous JavaScript where array $[index] is used, we get the result shown in Figure 11 below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_142989\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 11. Decoded JavaScript code shows the iframe code that will be injected into the HTML page.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe decoded script checks for a document.referrer, meaning the traffic must have been directed from a different source, instead of directly typing a URL or domain into the web browser bar. In this case, the script is checking for a referral from one of many popular search engines. Then, depending on which search engine was used, the script will use the random ElementID present inside the page and add an iframe containing the malicious domain using the innerHTML property highlighted in blue in Figure 11 above. This ensures that traffic originating from these search engines is redirected to the injected link.\r\n\r\nThe script also extracts data following the # character in the viewer's URL. It then uses the atob function to decode Base64 text from this data and inject another iframe using the innerHTML property (Figure 12).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_143000\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 12. If the referral is not from any search engine, then it will use the code from the URL.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn Figures 11 and 12, code for the iframe includes a CSS property z-index with a value of 30000, and it has the iframe's width and height values as 100%, with left and top as zero. With these values, the iframe will cover the entire browser window and hide the original content. This means someone can only interact with the content from the iframe and not the webpage's actual content. This is a common technique used in clickjacking, phishing attacks and malicious redirects.\r\n\r\nFigure 13 shows a page from a legitimate website after redirection, leading to a ZIP archive download.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_143011\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 13. After redirection, the iframe shows content spoofing a hosting service and leading to a suspicious ZIP archive.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn Figure 13, note how the right side of the browser window contains two scroll bars. The outer scrollbar is for the legitimate webpage, while the inner scrollbar is for the iframe.\r\nConclusion\r\nThis analysis demonstrated how malicious JavaScript obfuscated with JSFireTruck redirects victims to unintended websites and unwanted content.\r\n\r\nWebsite injection is a common attack method. Each day, thousands of legitimate websites are compromised in this manner. These compromised but legitimate websites can lead to malicious content, like pages serving unwanted content, exploits or malware.\r\n\r\nWebsite administrators must keep their web servers up to date with the latest security updates, and administrators should also analyze their web servers for any signs of infection or compromise.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:\r\n\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the IoCs shared in this research.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify URLs and domains that host similar obfuscated JavaScript as malicious.\r\n \tCortex Cloud provides Web Applications and API Security (WAAS) protection through the runtime detection of OWASP Top 10 API risks, configuration drift such as misconfigurations and vulnerabilities and security breaches. Including, SQL injection (SQLi), Cross-site scripting (XSS), CVE exploit attempts, authentication bypass, sensitive data leakage, bot and scanner activity, and traffic anomalies. Cor\u200b\u200btex Cloud protects WAAS infrastructure from the threats discussed within this article.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 00080005045107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nSHA256 for 25 examples of webpages with injected script using JSFireTruck obfuscation:\r\n\r\n \t03ba72c2b7b0e2a9c459b95646b4301840ae66b87de47d1117a44e2d2d3e3584\r\n \t044cb5f61172adb60a8bca0a7addadb6bb69107a4916057338c6578aa846b057\r\n \t0f7903f7822c6a958d94db1b5fe83a5032eaf40ef3439c9d7bf8beec66971615\r\n \t1476e45493ac53a8ee99fae8c3ac6b80ba724de0bba4c995f9d4c506c2f38165\r\n \t17e9650f044dda1c48854e460a3cd9fe092ddc11c2e8631fed9ec293b1df2a6a\r\n \t1fdc283f40e64818fc5dace2a7416d1d7bd1e494e28f759ac600958f55d25dfb\r\n \t2053fc3b075a4661ffead5a5aebcf32a4e6fcff3c67519da7e7b0ca887e27c67\r\n \t21b1ff38713db80d78393b28e345de9dac97e3a69242de849555a0b6c9beee45\r\n \t2c452a201153e0c6c9aa2f53496d9fb43accb1a6939fe1dad8b9941fdedd0002\r\n \t3378883ded7d58334d375584e3b1e8a78f6db1e4f024bb2b8fd7b2b44a5233d2\r\n \t34c427d2e8b83877cae2a6b7c9afddf2c58efef203e44f01aaca115d99cb9e37\r\n \t4a90e10d497d35306bbe2db4f7d35beb0aac3468f46cef497a8438f89e63b8b7\r\n \t4e96d39e316fe179dff7e23c7817f0333aac6f19733a93ec4a6d6ec0c5c3ce65\r\n \t6105f6bb9b3f11babc219aab72d5c0cfb61feb1c0d9da06835c66ce3b180f97a\r\n \t6f545f17b2111f84aea5319e8425d1219c4202c2bf634013af2dec9f358a7625\r\n \t76578de2041f34b550a963f286827e75112ee608314611df9bc1fdb195b8838d\r\n \t7d840b55806e1b6e733d416cffa472978f8ff574b3d87131a40d99447189ed52\r\n \t9aa62bcc51798458e79f36b5812cd0ba2b62f4388d4f36f04708880601fb37ec\r\n \t9e42e7df0921b694be99c50db3bbd25ed6cf8a21ba3a4f2c0c56623e8e0db570\r\n \tae99713386f4497131473d901f006548fde88e9f78cadfad720e5a1c7850586a\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    </head>
<body class="wp-singular post-template-default single single-post postid-142866 single-format-standard wp-theme-unit42-v6 no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">
        <button class="btn__search" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#search" aria-label="search"><i class="ui ui-1"></i></button>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">

                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=aa004e3a1f" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=aa004e3a1f" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>
                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">

				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fmalicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=JSFireTruck:%20Exploring%20Malicious%20JavaScript%20Using%20JSF*ck%20as%20an%20Obfuscation%20Technique%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fmalicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-javascript-using-jsfiretruck-as-obfuscation:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-142866-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>We recently discovered a large-scale campaign that has been compromising legitimate websites with injected, obfuscated JavaScript code. Threat actors commonly use this type of campaign to invisibly redirect victims from legitimate websites to malicious pages that serve malware, exploits and spam.</p>
<p>The campaign uses a JavaScript obfuscation technique known as JSF*ck (profanity masked). Due to the profanity in the term, we refer to the method in the remainder of this article by using the nickname JSFireTruck.</p>
<p>Our key findings are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Multiple websites have been identified with injected malicious JavaScript that uses JSFireTruck obfuscation, which is composed primarily of the symbols <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]+${}</span></li>
<li>The code's obfuscation hides its true purpose, hindering analysis</li>
<li>The injected code checks the website referrer, and if the referrer is a search engine, the code redirects victims to malicious URLs</li>
<li>Retroactive hunting on VirusTotal and our internal telemetry revealed thousands of related samples, indicating this is a widespread infection campaign affecting many websites</li>
<li>Injected JavaScript will redirect users to websites that can lead to malware downloads or other harmful activities, like malvertising and traffic monetization</li>
</ul>
<p>The campaign's scale and stealth pose a significant threat. The widespread nature of these infections suggests a coordinated effort to compromise legitimate websites as attack vectors for further malicious activities.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/malvertising/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Malvertising</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/javascript/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JavaScript</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-142866-_p62uxphtr0oz"></a>Background</h2>
<p>Attackers compromise legitimate websites, so these sites will silently redirect viewer traffic for various malicious purposes, like malware downloads, traffic monetization or malvertising. Our telemetry recently revealed a large group of websites that were injected with malicious obfuscated JavaScript, as shown below in Figure 1.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142879" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142879" style="width: 834px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142879 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-148013-142866-1.png" alt="The image displays a piece of code with various functions and characters, formatted in colorful text on a dark background." width="834" height="277" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-148013-142866-1.png 834w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-148013-142866-1-786x261.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-148013-142866-1-768x255.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 834px) 100vw, 834px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142879" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Example of malicious injected JavaScript found in the HTML pages.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On an initial look, the JavaScript code consists of a few characters like <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]+${}</span> and some numbers. The code's purpose isn't readily apparent, prompting further investigation. We soon discovered that this code partially implements the <a href="https://github.com/aemkei/jsfuck" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JSFireTruck programming technique</a>.</p>
<p>Our telemetry detected 269,552 webpages infected with JavaScript code using JSFireTruck in the three months from March 26, 2025, through April 25, 2025. This data is shown below in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142890" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142890" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142890 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-152002-142866-2.png" alt="A bar chart displaying daily hit counts from March 27, 2025, to April 25, 2025, with a significant peak in April. The y-axis is labeled 'Count' and the x-axis represents the dates." width="1000" height="291" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-152002-142866-2.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-152002-142866-2-786x229.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-152002-142866-2-1920x559.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-152002-142866-2-768x224.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-152002-142866-2-1536x447.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142890" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Telemetry data shows over 200,000 infected pages.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As indicated in Figure 2, we saw a notable increase in detections for this campaign starting on April 12, 2025. Ultimately, this campaign is widespread and has infected many websites.</p>
<h2><a id="post-142866-_sylk4in5fzo8"></a>Analyzing the JavaScript Obfuscation</h2>
<p>The injected JavaScript code with JSFireTruck obfuscation uses a limited set of characters and numbers, as shown in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142901" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142901" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142901 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-156075-142866-3.png" alt="A matrix of hexadecimal green characters on a black background." width="1000" height="281" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-156075-142866-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-156075-142866-3-786x221.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-156075-142866-3-1920x540.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-156075-142866-3-768x216.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-156075-142866-3-1536x432.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142901" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Injected code as found in the HTML page consists of only <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">]</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">)</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">!</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+</span> and numbers.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This is unexpected compared to examples of malicious injected JavaScript code we normally find, as there is no single variable or function name that seems to be executed at first glance. But publicly available information indicates that the symbols from this code are ASCII characters used for JSFireTruck.</p>
<p>JSFireTruck is a branch of an earlier JavaScript obfuscation technique originally released in 2009 called <a href="https://utf-8.jp/public/jjencode.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JJEncode</a>. This earlier technique was used in previous campaigns to obfuscate JavaScript, <a href="https://www.kahusecurity.com/posts/jjencode_script_leads_to_drive-by.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">like Kahu Security's 2013 analysis of a compromised automobile forum</a>. JJEncode uses the following 18 ASCII characters: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]()!+,\"$.:;_{}~=</span></p>
<p>By August 2012, a user named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">aemkei</span> <a href="https://github.com/aemkei/jsfuck/tree/d274487af8b8f291b27ca79ceaabe736b62d0f79" target="_blank" rel="noopener">created a GitHub repository for JSFireTruck</a>, where they reduced the number of ASCII characters to the following six symbols:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">]</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">)</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">!</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+</span></p>
<p>The example from Figure 3 above appears to combine JSFireTruck with other obfuscation techniques.</p>
<h2><a id="post-142866-_3vyeycu2ekjl"></a>JavaScript Obfuscation Through Type Coercion</h2>
<p>JavaScript has different value types like strings, numbers, booleans, arrays and objects. If we use two mismatched value types together, such as strings and numbers, JavaScript uses <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Data_structures#type_coercion" target="_blank" rel="noopener">type coercion</a> to make the code work. Type coercion results in converting a value from one type to another.</p>
<p>Type coercion has various uses, such as displaying a number in JavaScript code as a string. For example, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">toString()</span> method will display a numeric value as an ASCII string.</p>
<p>JSFireTruck relies on type coercion, which automatically converts its limited set of symbols into the various ASCII characters or numeric values used in unobfuscated JavaScript code.</p>
<p>For example, to generate a number value of zero, we can use the following characters:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+[]</span></p>
<p>If we debug the characters <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+[]</span> in Chrome or Edge DevTools, we find these characters translate to a value of zero, as shown below in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142912" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142912" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142912 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-159800-142866-4.png" alt="A screenshot of the Google Chrome DevTools interface, focusing on the Sources panel. The image highlights the right-click menu option &quot;Evaluate selected text in console&quot; with a cursor pointing to it, and shows other development tools and icons. The converted value is in the Console pane. " width="1000" height="676" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-159800-142866-4.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-159800-142866-4-651x440.png 651w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-159800-142866-4-1035x700.png 1035w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-159800-142866-4-768x519.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-159800-142866-4-1536x1038.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142912" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Using DevTools to convert JavaScript code <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+[]</span> to its numeric value of zero.</figcaption></figure>
<p>How is this possible? In JavaScript code, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]</span> represents an empty array, and if we prefix it with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+</span>, JavaScript will use type coercion to convert the empty array value into a number. Since <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]</span> contains no value, using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+</span> converts it to a value of zero.</p>
<p>Using this approach, we can generate the number <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1</span> with the following characters:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+!![]</span></p>
<p>Because the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]</span> array is blank, prefixing it with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">!</span> converts it to the boolean value of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">False</span>. Adding a second <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">!</span> converts it to a boolean value of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">True</span>. Prefixing the entire string with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+</span> converts it to a numeric value. When converting <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">True</span> to a number, its value is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1</span>.</p>
<p>We can generate other numbers by adding the same <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+!![]</span> text, which represents an additional value of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1</span>. For example, we can generate the number <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2</span> from:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+!![] + +!![]</span></p>
<p>We can generate the number 3 from:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+!![] + +!![] + +!![]</span></p>
<p>Similarly, we can increase the numeric value by adding more <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+!![]</span> text to the string.</p>
<p>We can also generate characters using this approach. For example, to create the character <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a</span>, we can use the following code:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(![]+[])[1]</span></p>
<p>In this example, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">![]</span> becomes the boolean value <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">False</span> as mentioned earlier. Adding the symbols for a blank array <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]</span> makes the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">![]+[]</span>, which represents <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">False +</span> no value. JavaScript uses type coercion to convert <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">![]+[]</span> to the ASCII string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">False</span>.</p>
<p>To select the second letter of the word <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">F<strong>a</strong>lse</span>, we need the first offset (second character) of the string. We do this by enclosing the original symbols in parentheses and using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1</span> for the offset, so <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(![]+[])[1]</span> is the code that generates the letter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a</span>.</p>
<p>Figure 5 shows Edge DevTools confirming that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(![]+[])[1]</span> generates the letter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142923" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142923" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142923 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-164419-142866-5.png" alt="A screenshot of the Google Chrome DevTools interface, focusing on the Sources panel. The image highlights the right-click menu option &quot;Evaluate selected text in console&quot; with a cursor pointing to it, and shows other development tools and icons. The converted value is in the Console pane. " width="1000" height="676" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-164419-142866-5.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-164419-142866-5-651x440.png 651w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-164419-142866-5-1035x700.png 1035w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-164419-142866-5-768x519.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-164419-142866-5-1536x1038.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142923" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Analysis of JavaScript code in DevTools showing how to generate the character <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a</span> with this approach.</figcaption></figure>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>In a similar manner, we can generate the character <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b</span> using the following string:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">({}+[])[2]</span></p>
<p>In this example, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">{}</span> represents an empty object. Adding the symbols for a blank array <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[]</span> makes the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">{}+[]</span>. JavaScript's type coercion changes <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">{}+[]</span> to the ASCII string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[object Object]</span>. To select the second letter of the word object in the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[o<strong>b</strong>ject Object]</span>, we need the second offset (third character) of that string. We do this by enclosing the original symbols in parentheses and using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2</span> for the offset, so <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">({}+[])[2]</span> is the code that generates the letter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b</span>.</p>
<p>Figure 6 shows Edge DevTools confirming that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">({}+[])[2]</span> generates the letter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142934" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142934" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142934 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-168285-142866-6.png" alt="A screenshot of the Google Chrome DevTools interface, focusing on the Sources panel. The image highlights the right-click menu option &quot;Evaluate selected text in console&quot; with a cursor pointing to it, and shows other development tools and icons. The converted value is in the Console pane. " width="1000" height="530" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-168285-142866-6.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-168285-142866-6-786x417.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-168285-142866-6-1320x700.png 1320w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-168285-142866-6-768x407.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-168285-142866-6-1536x814.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142934" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Analysis of JavaScript code in DevTools showing how to generate the character <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b</span> with this approach.</figcaption></figure>
<p>By using different combinations of symbols and terms, JavaScript's type coercion can generate various ASCII strings. We can use the offset method to select each letter of the alphabet and different symbols from the resulting strings. Figure 7 shows examples analyzed in DevTools that result in the letters <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142945" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142945" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142945 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-172272-142866-7.png" alt="Screenshot of DevTools with the Console tab selected, displaying code outputs in a console with various obfuscation examples in JavaScript." width="800" height="450" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-172272-142866-7.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-172272-142866-7-782x440.png 782w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-172272-142866-7-1244x700.png 1244w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-172272-142866-7-768x432.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-172272-142866-7-1536x864.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142945" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Examples of this obfuscation approach in DevTools that generate the letters <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>From this approach, we can further condense the symbols to the six used by JSFireTruck: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">]</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">)</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">!</span>, and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">+</span>. For example, we can generate the letters <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b</span> from the following characters:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a = (![]+[])[+!![]]</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b = ({}+[])[+!![] + +!![]]</span></p>
<p>By using the JSFireTruck obfuscation technique, any JavaScript code can be obfuscated by using just six characters. Furthermore, attackers can combine JSFireTruck with other obfuscation techniques to make malicious JavaScript more difficult for defenders to analyze.</p>
<p>But using these obfuscation techniques has two drawbacks:</p>
<ul>
<li>The obfuscated code usually involves a large amount of text</li>
<li>Due to the repeated use of the same characters, the obfuscated code is easy to detect, even if it is not easy to analyze</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-142866-_22ugw9731az7"></a>Example of Malicious Code</h2>
<p>We now understand how just six characters can represent any JavaScript code. Malware authors use this technique to make code analysis more difficult.</p>
<p>During our analysis, we found thousands of websites with this type of obfuscated JavaScript injected into their webpages.</p>
<p>Figure 8 below shows an example of the injected script following the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">String.fromCharCode</span> function.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142956" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142956" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142956 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-176573-142866-8.png" alt="Image displaying a portion of JavaScript code with a div element and variable declarations, involving string manipulations and array operations." width="1000" height="454" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-176573-142866-8.png 2028w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-176573-142866-8-786x357.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-176573-142866-8-1543x700.png 1543w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-176573-142866-8-768x348.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-176573-142866-8-1536x697.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142956" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Example of injected code starting from the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">String.fromCharCode</span> function.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Of note, the obfuscated script contains an additional <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">String.fromCharCode</span> function, which presents another obfuscation layer.</p>
<h2><a id="post-142866-_areytxrnl7f1"></a>Decoding the Obfuscated Script</h2>
<p>We can decode the obfuscated JavaScript shown in Figure 8 through various publicly available deobfuscators for JSFireTruck. We automated our decoding process using <a href="https://github.com/cilame/unjsfuck" target="_blank" rel="noopener">one such tool</a>.</p>
<p>When the script from Figure 8 is decoded, the output appears to be further obfuscated as shown in Figure 9.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142967" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142967" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142967 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-180458-142866-9.png" alt="Image displaying a line of code with a mix of numbers, Boolean values, and text strings, mostly related to various properties such as IDs, indexes, counts, and sizes." width="1000" height="354" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-180458-142866-9.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-180458-142866-9-786x278.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-180458-142866-9-1920x679.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-180458-142866-9-768x272.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-180458-142866-9-1536x543.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142967" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Decoded JSFireTruck script shows that it's further obfuscated.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The decoded script remains obfuscated, using an array variable <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">$</span>. It then accesses the values at different indexes within this array.</p>
<p>These array variables are present inside the script shown in Figure 10.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142978" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142978" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142978 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-185493-142866-10.png" alt="Screenshot of injected code with a portion highlighted in yellow." width="1000" height="83" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-185493-142866-10.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-185493-142866-10-786x65.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-185493-142866-10-1920x159.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-185493-142866-10-768x64.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-185493-142866-10-1536x128.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142978" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Injected code showing use of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">String.fromCharCode</span> function used as an array.</figcaption></figure>
<p>If we decode these character arrays and use them to replace the characters in the previous JavaScript where array <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">$[index]</span> is used, we get the result shown in Figure 11 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_142989" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-142989" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-142989 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-188951-142866-11.png" alt="A screenshot of computer code in an editor, highlighting a script involving conditional checks for referrers from well-known search engines such as Google, Bing, DuckDuckGo, Yahoo, and AOL. The code includes HTML manipulation to insert an iframe. Parts of the code and URLs are intentionally blurred for privacy." width="1000" height="408" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-188951-142866-11.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-188951-142866-11-786x320.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-188951-142866-11-1717x700.png 1717w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-188951-142866-11-768x313.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-188951-142866-11-1536x626.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-142989" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Decoded JavaScript code shows the iframe code that will be injected into the HTML page.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The decoded script checks for a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">document.referrer</span>, meaning the traffic must have been directed from a different source, instead of directly typing a URL or domain into the web browser bar. In this case, the script is checking for a referral from one of many popular search engines. Then, depending on which search engine was used, the script will use the random <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ElementID</span> present inside the page and add an iframe containing the malicious domain using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">innerHTML</span> property highlighted in blue in Figure 11 above. This ensures that traffic originating from these search engines is redirected to the injected link.</p>
<p>The script also extracts data following the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">#</span> character in the viewer's URL. It then uses the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">atob</span> function to decode Base64 text from this data and inject another iframe using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">innerHTML</span> property (Figure 12).</p>
<figure id="attachment_143000" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-143000" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-143000 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-193535-142866-12.png" alt="A screenshot of code in an IDE, highlighting a JavaScript snippet checking the URL for specific parameters related to search engines like Yahoo, AOL, and DuckDuckGo. A portion of the code injecting an iframe is highlighted in a box. Parts of the code and URLs are intentionally blurred for privacy." width="1000" height="408" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-193535-142866-12.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-193535-142866-12-786x320.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-193535-142866-12-1717x700.png 1717w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-193535-142866-12-768x313.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-193535-142866-12-1536x626.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-143000" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. If the referral is not from any search engine, then it will use the code from the URL.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In Figures 11 and 12, code for the iframe includes a CSS property <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">z-index</span> with a value of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">30000</span>, and it has the iframe's <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">width</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">height</span> values as 100%, with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">left</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">top</span> as zero. With these values, the iframe will cover the entire browser window and hide the original content. This means someone can only interact with the content from the iframe and not the webpage's actual content. This is a common technique used in clickjacking, phishing attacks and malicious redirects.</p>
<p>Figure 13 shows a page from a legitimate website after redirection, leading to a ZIP archive download.</p>
<figure id="attachment_143011" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-143011" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-143011 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-198185-142866-13.png" alt="Screenshot of a spoofed MediaFire download page displaying an option to download a vector drawing app for Mac. The page highlights a button labeled &quot;Download&quot; and provides information about the file, including its type as a ZIP archive." width="1000" height="526" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-198185-142866-13.png 1886w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-198185-142866-13-786x413.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-198185-142866-13-1331x700.png 1331w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-198185-142866-13-768x404.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/word-image-198185-142866-13-1536x808.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-143011" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. After redirection, the iframe shows content spoofing a hosting service and leading to a suspicious ZIP archive.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In Figure 13, note how the right side of the browser window contains two scroll bars. The outer scrollbar is for the legitimate webpage, while the inner scrollbar is for the iframe.</p>
<h2><a id="post-142866-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This analysis demonstrated how malicious JavaScript obfuscated with JSFireTruck redirects victims to unintended websites and unwanted content.</p>
<p>Website injection is a common attack method. Each day, thousands of legitimate websites are compromised in this manner. These compromised but legitimate websites can lead to malicious content, like pages serving unwanted content, exploits or malware.</p>
<p>Website administrators must keep their web servers up to date with the latest security updates, and administrators should also analyze their web servers for any signs of infection or compromise.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the IoCs shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify URLs and domains that host similar obfuscated JavaScript as malicious.</li>
<li>Cortex Cloud provides <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Cloud-Documentation/Web-and-API-Security-WAAS" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Web Applications and API Security</a> (WAAS) protection through the runtime detection of OWASP Top 10 API risks, configuration drift such as misconfigurations and vulnerabilities and security breaches. Including, SQL injection (SQLi), Cross-site scripting (XSS), CVE exploit attempts, authentication bypass, sensitive data leakage, bot and scanner activity, and traffic anomalies. Cor​​tex Cloud protects WAAS infrastructure from the threats discussed within this article.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>
